column2: First FTC privacy enforcement action (Deceptive). Resold PI after promising not to.
First FTC action mandating a comprehensive information privacy/security program. Triggered by accidental email leak of 600 users.
Rent-to-own company secretly installed spyware (Detective Mode) on computers to capture keystrokes/images. Deemed **Unfair** (intrusive monitoring).
Failed to implement strong security despite advertising claims. Violated prior consent decree -> $100M fine.
Deceptive claims about user privacy control (allowing dev access despite 'friends only' settings). Violated prior decree -> $5B fine.
Deceptive certification. Failed to conduct required annual recertifications of clients while displaying Trust Mark.
3rd Circuit affirmed FTC Section 5 authority to regulate cybersecurity as 'Unfair'. Established 'fair notice'.
11th Circuit vacated FTC order for being too vague. 'Reasonable security' is unenforceable; orders need concrete directives.
Failed to use Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) and stored unencrypted geolocation data in cloud.
Pre-installed 'man-in-the-middle' adware (Superfish) that compromised browser encryption.
Falsely claimed 'bank-grade security' without a written security program. Deceptive.
First child privacy case against an IoT maker. Failed to encrypt data/implement intrusion detection.
Massive breach ($575M settlement). Failed to patch known vulnerabilities and segment servers.
Smart lock maker falsely claimed to be 'unbreakable'. API vulnerabilities allowed bypass.
Exposed health data in unsecured cloud; displayed fake 'HIPAA Compliance' seal.
Violated GLBA Safeguards Rule by failing to oversee a vendor (Vendor Oversight).
First application of **Algorithmic Disgorgement**. Required deletion of facial recognition models trained on improperly obtained data.
